S1.T1.footnotes: It may be possible to implement, but was not evaluated.
references:
A consensus-based multi-hop federated distillation (CMFD) is developed as a NN version of the meta-algorithm because it cannot be implemented directly.
Fig. 1 shows an overview of our CMFD,
and the characteristics of CMFD are compared with other FL algorithms in Table I.
CMFD addresses one of the impracticalities of the meta-algorithm: the difficulty of aggregating prediction functions in a function space.
Because boosting algorithms, for example, GBDT, are functional gradient methods as explained in [21],
the meta-algorithm is easily applied to boosting algorithms by considering weak learners as functional gradients.
However, stochastic gradient descent (SGD)-based algorithms for NN are parametric, and an implementation scheme must be developed.
The calculation of aggregated prediction functions among adjacent devices is a technical problem
because it is difficult to determine the parameters 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} that satisfy f​(𝒙;𝒘)=∑ifi​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙𝒘subscript𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙f(\bm{x};\bm{w})=\sum_{i}f_{i}(\bm{x}) for given prediction functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}.

We show a toy model how CMFD tackles function aggregation using distillation in Appendix A.

S5.T2.table:

references:
We evaluated CMFD using the public datasets, MNIST [38], fashion MNIST (F-MNIST) [39], CIFAR10, and CIFAR100 [40].
The simulation parameters are presented in Table II.
Ten devices were assumed to be connected via multi-hop networks, as shown in Fig. 3.
We evaluated the R1, R2, and R3 ring lattice networks and BA1 and BA3 scale-free networks
that are occasionally used in WSNs for energy efficiency [41].
The evaluated scale-free networks were generated using the Barabási–Albert (BA) algorithm [42].
In our simulations, the devices had two types of labels to evaluate the non-IID situations.
When evaluating ring networks,
device #​i#𝑖\#i possessed training data labeled i𝑖i and ((i+1)mod10)modulo𝑖110((i+1)\bmod 10) for 10-class classification tasks
and 10​i10𝑖10i through ((10​i+19)mod100)modulo10𝑖19100((10i+19)\bmod 100) for CIFAR100
assuming a situation where nearby devices had similar data distributions,
where modmodulo\bmod denotes the modulo operator.
Conversely, when evaluating scale-free networks,
two types of labels were chosen randomly.
One thousand public data samples without ground truth labels were used for the distillation.
The local and public datasets were allowed to duplicate.
The NN layer architecture was CNN(32,532532,5)-CNN(64,564564,5)-FC(512512512)-FC(101010)111CNN(f,k𝑓𝑘f,k) and FC(n𝑛n) represent the convolution layer with f𝑓f-filters with a kernel size of k×k𝑘𝑘k\times k and the fully connected layer with n𝑛n-hidden nodes..
ReLU was used as the activation function.

We conducted another simulation using three types of models—model A, MobileNetV3 Small [43], and ResNet18 [44]—to verify whether CMFD can learn more complex models in heterogeneous settings.
Fig. 6 shows the accuracy as a function of the number of epochs when five or ten devices learn F-MNIST.
Each line represents the average accuracy among all devices.
When the number of devices is five, each device possesses a dataset consisting of four categories,
and the number of local data samples is 2000.
The dropout rate was set to 0.1, and the other parameters are listed in Table II.
The input images were resized to 96×96969696\times 96 before being input into MobileNetV3 and ResNet18
because these models are considerably deep, and the image sizes decrease to one pixel in the last layer without expansion.
We substituted layer normalization [45] for batch normalization [46] in MobileNetV3 and ResNet18
because batch normalization is not suitable for non-IID datasets [6].
Fig. 6 shows that CMFD can train models with non-IID datasets in heterogeneous scenarios
even though the numbers of the layers of the models are widely different:
Model A has only four layers, while MobileNetV3 Small and ResNet18 have 16 and 18 layers, respectively.

references:
Table III lists the average accuracy and the other two metrics at 1000 epochs (F-MNIST) and 2000 epochs (CIFAR10 and CIFAR100) with various parameters.
Metric max-min shows the difference in the accuracy of the best and the worse devices,
which is a metric of convergence among devices.
Label dev shows the averaged standard deviation of each device’s accuracy during the last 100 epochs.
Values of max-min confirm that
when the learning rate and the sharing rate were well-tuned,
the accuracies of the ten devices
converged in narrower ranges with CMFD than parameter averaging.
By comparing the deviations of the two methods, the fluctuation range of CMFD is approximately one-tenth that of parameter averaging.
The difference in stability occurs because the parameter-averaging algorithm attempts to solve a non-convex optimization problem,
whereas CMFD is designed to solve a convex optimization problem in a function space.
Because there are multiple local optima in a parameter space, when the parameters of devices tend toward different optima,
the parameter-updating directions calculated by parameter sharing and gradient descent can differ completely.
Conversely, the local prediction functions of devices draw close in a function space by CMFD,
which allows different parameters if they are located at the same point in a function space.
This difference in stability is significant, especially if the devices are weakly connected,
because the variance of the parameter-updating directions increases owing to the small number of adjacent devices
when using the parameter-averaging scheme.
In contrast, CMFD, which aims to aggregate functions directly,
is not exposed to a major variance in the function-updating directions even with few adjacent devices.

Table III lists the evaluated results of PDMM [6] as the state-of-the-art decentralized FL.
The communication frequency of PDMM is set such that the number of transmissions is approximately same as CMFD and parameter averaging
because PDMM is an asynchronous algorithm, whereas CMFD is a synchronous algorithm.
In this setting, the amount of transmitted data is twice as large as that of parameter averaging.
Although PDMM achieves high convergence among devices and high accuracy even when devices are weakly connected,
CMFD outperforms PDMM in terms of accuracy on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.
CMFD regards learning tasks as convex function optimization problems,
whereas PDMM and parameter averaging attempt to solve non-convex optimization problems in the parameter space.
Therefore, CMFD achieves higher accuracy for difficult tasks compared with the other methods.

S5.T4.table:
Topology R1 R2 R3 BA1 BA2
Algebraic connectivity 0.38 1.76 4.38 0.18 1.42

references:
Various topologies are compared in Fig. 7, which shows the average accuracy as a function of the sharing rate.
The accuracy indicated by the label “BA (dynamic)” shows the performance when the network topology dynamically changed at each epoch
to evaluate situations where the mobile devices were in motion.
This shows that even if the topology changes dynamically, the accuracy converges to the same value.
Notably, these results also support that CMFD is highly stable even when it is applied via wireless networks with considerable noise
because a dynamic topology emulates a situation with unstable links.
When comparing the topologies, the accuracy of R3 was slightly better than that of R2, BA2, and dynamic BA.
However, the accuracy of R1 and BA1 was poorer than that of the others.
These differences arise from the algebraic connectivity λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} in (24) and (26).
Table IV lists the algebraic connectivities and average degrees of the evaluated topologies.
Because the connectivity of R2, BA2, and dynamic BA are similar, they achieved similar performance.
Similarly, the accuracy of R1 and BA1 were similar because they had similar connectivity.

S5.T5.caption: TABLE V: Connectivity with various numbers of devices
S5.T5.table:
Num. devices 10 20 40 60 80 100
Algebraic connectivity 1.41 1.44 1.40 1.37 1.35 1.32
Average of degrees 4.2 5.1 5.55 5.7 5.775 5.82
references:
Fig. 8 shows the average accuracy and distillation losses for various numbers of devices.
The distillation loss is MSE c​(𝒘^i)𝑐subscript^𝒘𝑖c({\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}), defined in (27).
This metric indicates the similarity of NN models among adjacent devices
because MSE is an empirical representation of the Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} distance.
It is shown that distillation losses decrease with the number of epochs,
which means that the local models approach each other in the function space,
even though the parameters of the local models are not forced to converge by CMFD.
Topologies varied at each epoch using the BA algorithm,
but the number of all edges remained stable.
The connectivity for different numbers of devices are listed in Table V.
The listed algebraic connectivity reflects the averages of 100 randomly generated graphs.
When evaluating MNIST, the learning and sharing rates were set to 0.01 and 0.1, respectively.
Both rates were set to 0.1 when evaluating F-MNIST.
Fig. 8 shows that even when the number of devices increases,
the NN models converge at nearly the same rate.
This is because, as shown in Table V, the averages of algebraic connectivity are approximately the same regardless of the number of devices.
These results indicate that the proposed algorithm works with a large number of devices
as long as the connectivity does not change drastically.
